header.title: The relationship between mathematics and physics

text.p: Mathematics is the language of physics
To study physics you need a certain level of fluency in it's language
Here are some of the commoon mathematical operations you need to be able to understand and perform in order to do Physics.
I will assume you know how to do these!

ul.li: Solve an equation with one unknown
Solve a group of related equations with several unknowns
Find the roots of a quadratic equation
Find the perimeter, area and volume of common shapes
Determine unknown angles from amongst a collection of straight lines

text.p: Multiplying a vector by a scalar is very simple. Just multiply each component by the scalar value.
To add two vectors, it is easiest to work in the "component" form of the vector.
Just take the x,y and z components of one vector and add them to the x,y and z components of the other vectors so:
$$\vec{a}=\vec{b}+\vec{c}\begin{cases} a_x = b_x + c_x\\ a_y = b_y + c_y\\ a_z = b_z + c_z \end{cases}$$
Just like in "normal" arithmetic, subtracting is just like adding but with a negative numbers. For example $5-3 \equiv 5+(-3)$.
$$\vec{a}=\vec{b}-\vec{c}=\vec{b}+(-\vec{c})\begin{cases} a_x = b_x-c_x\\ a_y = b_y-c_y\\ a_z = b_z-c_z \end{cases}$$
To add two vectors, it is easiest to work in the "component" form of the vector.
Just take the x,y and z components of one vector and add them to the x,y and z components of the other vectors so:
